articles.snippet: The storm is now a Category 4 storm forecast to sweep up the southeastern coast of the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hurricane Dorian is slowing to a crawl as it approaches the Bahamas, where it is forecast to remain until it takes a sharp swerve north along Florida’s eastern coast sometime on Monday. The Category 4 storm could make landfall in Georgia or the Carolinas as late as Thursday after losing some of its strength.
articles.abstract: The storm is now a Category 4 storm forecast to sweep up the southeastern coast of the United States.

headline.main: Hurricane Dorian Updates: Storm Gains Strength as Forecast Shifts

articles.snippet: Why do we continue to build in places prone to big storms and other disasters?
articles.lead_paragraph: Over the past 167 years, 40 percent of all hurricanes that scored direct hits on the United States struck Florida. So it shouldn’t be surprising that Dorian, the latest storm to emerge from the Atlantic, has drawn a bead on Florida’s east coast. As of now, it is expected to land somewhere there on Tuesday as a powerful Category 4 hurricane.
articles.abstract: Why do we continue to build in places prone to big storms and other disasters?

articles.snippet: After Hurricane Irma in 2017, a dozen patients died in a nursing home. The tragedy taught officials that evacuation orders were not enough to protect the state’s older population.
articles.lead_paragraph: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla. — As the outer bands of Hurricane Dorian began brushing the Florida coast on Tuesday, a woman raced to pick up her mother-in-law at a retirement community, where the elevator was about to be shut down. The staff of a nursing home packed up more than 200 residents as well as the supplies they might need: cases of water, air mattresses and board games. At another center, residents were evacuated in specialty ambulances, rented motor coaches and private vehicles.
articles.abstract: After Hurricane Irma in 2017, a dozen patients died in a nursing home. The tragedy taught officials that evacuation orders were not enough to protect the state’s older population.

headline.main: Hurricane Dorian Tests Florida’s Ability to Move Older Adults Out of Harm’s Way
headline.print_headline: Racing to Move Seniors at Risk To Dry Ground

byline.original: By Patricia Mazzei, Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs and Richard Fausset

articles.snippet: Mr. Trump has been the meteorologist in chief, adding constant weather updates to a usual weekend of tweets attacking his enemies and retweeting bits of praise.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Over the long weekend, President Trump monitored Hurricane Dorian from a golf cart at his club in Virginia, calling for regular updates from an aide trailing him around the course. By 8 p.m. Monday, as Dorian churned toward Florida and Mr. Trump’s  boarded-up Mar-a-Lago resort, the president had golfed twice and since Saturday morning pelted the American public with 122 tweets.
articles.abstract: Mr. Trump has been the meteorologist in chief, adding constant weather updates to a usual weekend of tweets attacking his enemies and retweeting bits of praise.

headline.main: President Trump, Weatherman: Dorian Updates and at Least 122 Tweets
headline.print_headline: Swirling Drama: Fitting a Hurricane Into Trump’s Twitter Feed

articles.snippet: The strongest storm to reach the northwestern Bahamas, with wind gusts up to 220 m.p.h, Hurricane Dorian brings “devastating” conditions.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hurricane Dorian slammed into the Bahamas Sunday, the strongest on record to hit the northwestern part of the archipelago, leaving residents seeking shelter as they faced rising waters, torrential rains and wind gusts up to 220 miles per hour.
articles.abstract: The strongest storm to reach the northwestern Bahamas, with wind gusts up to 220 m.p.h, Hurricane Dorian brings “devastating” conditions.

headline.main: Hurricane Dorian Batters Bahamas as ‘Catastrophic’ Storm

articles.snippet: Helicopter evacuations have begun, but relief workers are anxious for the chance to fly into the damaged areas.
articles.lead_paragraph: NASSAU, Bahamas — As Hurricane Dorian pulled away from the Bahamas, relief workers, medical personnel, pilots and others gathered at a private terminal of the Nassau airport on Wednesday amid boxes of supplies, anxiously awaiting permission from the government to fly to devastated areas and provide assistance.
articles.abstract: Helicopter evacuations have begun, but relief workers are anxious for the chance to fly into the damaged areas.

articles.snippet: Understanding and forecasting a giant storm requires knowledge, experience and data — a lot of it, though scientists could always use more.
articles.lead_paragraph: As Hurricane Dorian, one of the strongest storms ever recorded in the Atlantic, continues to batter the Bahamas and approach the United States mainland, millions of people who may be in its path are watching  — and worrying. We asked readers what they want to know about Dorian. Answering those questions is Prof. Adam Sobel, an atmospheric scientist and director of the Initiative on Extreme Weather and Climate at Columbia University and the author of “Storm Surge,” a book about Superstorm Sandy.
articles.abstract: Understanding and forecasting a giant storm requires knowledge, experience and data — a lot of it, though scientists could always use more.

articles.snippet: One big question about Hurricane Dorian remains: Will the ferocious storm cause significant damage in the United States?
articles.lead_paragraph: Hurricane Dorian’s clear eye and near-circular symmetry, apparent in satellite images, signify a ferocious storm. The Bahamas are in serious, imminent danger. But for all we know about Dorian, which reached Category 5 on the Saffir-Simpson scale on Sunday with maximum winds of 185 miles an hour, one big question remains: Will it be a disaster for the United States?
articles.abstract: One big question about Hurricane Dorian remains: Will the ferocious storm cause significant damage in the United States?

headline.main: A Storm Expert’s View: Dorian’s Damage Remains Impossible to Predict

byline.original: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs, Patricia Mazzei and Patrick J. Lyons

articles.snippet: A powerful Category 5 storm has bound together a disparate community of people across states and nations.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Norma Lemon, the owner of a Caribbean-themed restaurant on the South Carolina coast, knows well the power of a hurricane to shatter both property and lives. She can recall the distinctive sound of roofs being ripped away by the winds of Hurricane Hugo as it tore though Charleston in 1989. She spent nearly three months restoring her Island Breeze restaurant after it was flooded by Hurricane Irma in 2017.
articles.abstract: A powerful Category 5 storm has bound together a disparate community of people across states and nations.

headline.main: Along Hurricane Dorian’s Tortured Path, Millions Are United in Fear

articles.snippet: Dorian may be super-powerful, but it’s moving at a snail’s pace. That gives its torrential rains more time to produce floods, and its winds more time to destroy.
articles.lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Hurricane Dorian, one of the most powerful Atlantic storms on record, hung over the Bahamas on Monday, thrashing the archipelago with high winds and surging seawater that flooded neighborhoods, submerged vehicles and shredded homes. The storm has left at least five people dead, officials said.
articles.abstract: Dorian may be super-powerful, but it’s moving at a snail’s pace. That gives its torrential rains more time to produce floods, and its winds more time to destroy.

articles.abstract: Homes inundated with water up to their roofs. Desperate residents wading through the storm surge. Cars submerged on flooded roods. Images from the hurricane show widespread destruction.

articles.snippet: Here are a few of the organizations that are working to bring food, water, medicine and other essentials to the Bahamas after the hurricane.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hurricane Dorian struck the northern Bahamas as a Category 5 hurricane on Sunday and stalled over the Abaco Islands and Grand Bahama Island for two days. The destructive winds, torrential rains and relentless flooding has likely destroyed more than 10,000 homes and wiped out much of the infrastructure, especially in the Abacos.

articles.lead_paragraph: Hurricane Dorian, which has already battered the Bahamas and left at least 23 dead there, is now pounding the southeastern United States. Many living in the region have experienced hurricanes for years, suffering through the loss of homes, livelihoods and even loved ones.
articles.abstract: As Hurricane Dorian bears down on the southeastern United States, we’re hoping to hear from readers who have lived through a number of major storms.

articles.snippet: A nephew of the acclaimed Bahamian-American actor said that he has been searching for his sister and her children, among others, since the hurricane hit: “We haven’t been able to find any of them.”
articles.lead_paragraph: In the aftermath of Hurricane Dorian, which left the Bahamas splintered and overcome with flooding, one prominent family with extensive connections in the islands has spent a week trying to account for missing relatives — and to maintain hope.
articles.abstract: A nephew of the acclaimed Bahamian-American actor said that he has been searching for his sister and her children, among others, since the hurricane hit: “We haven’t been able to find any of them.”

headline.main: Feared Missing in the Bahamas: 23 Relatives of Sidney Poitier

headline.main: Brexit, Syria, Hurricane Dorian: Your Wednesday Briefing

articles.snippet: After assaulting the Bahamas and skirting past Florida, the sprawling storm began sweeping north through the Carolinas.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHARLESTON, S.C. — After its deadly rampage across the Bahamas and brush of Florida, Hurricane Dorian pounded the Carolinas on Thursday as its center closed in on Cape Fear, N.C., sowing fear and worry from the elegant streets of downtown Charleston to the jigsaw puzzle that is North Carolina’s barrier islands.
articles.abstract: After assaulting the Bahamas and skirting past Florida, the sprawling storm began sweeping north through the Carolinas.

headline.main: Hurricane Dorian Becomes a Carolina Problem With a Fierce Lashing of the Coast
headline.print_headline: Churning North,  Hurricane Drubs  Weary Carolinas

byline.original: By Richard Fausset and Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs

articles.snippet: Against all odds, Brent Lowe escaped the wrath of Hurricane Dorian. Now the real struggle begins.
articles.lead_paragraph: NASSAU, the Bahamas — The roof had blown clean off. Outside, the ocean surged, swallowing the land. Brent Lowe knew he had to escape — and take his 24-year-old son, who has cerebral palsy and can’t walk, with him.
articles.abstract: Against all odds, Brent Lowe escaped the wrath of Hurricane Dorian. Now the real struggle begins.

headline.main: In Bahamas, a Blind Father Wades to Safety, His Disabled Son on His Shoulders
headline.print_headline: Blind and Wading, Son in Tow, to Relative Safety

articles.snippet: The National Hurricane Center warned of “life-threatening” storm surge along hundreds of miles of the Southeast coast, even before the storm’s high winds arrive.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hurricane Dorian, which caused widespread devastation in the Bahamas, was churning on Wednesday off the Atlantic coast, and residents along hundreds of miles of shoreline were warned of its potential for life-threatening storm surge and dangerous winds.
articles.abstract: The National Hurricane Center warned of “life-threatening” storm surge along hundreds of miles of the Southeast coast, even before the storm’s high winds arrive.

articles.snippet: In the wake of Hurricane Dorian, Hampton University will open its doors to students from the University of the Bahamas.
articles.lead_paragraph: More than 800 miles separate the University of the Bahamas and Hampton University in Virginia. But some students at the former, whose north campus was devastated by Hurricane Dorian, will be able to continue their education at no cost at the latter for a semester.
articles.abstract: In the wake of Hurricane Dorian, Hampton University will open its doors to students from the University of the Bahamas.

headline.main: A Virginia University Offers Free Semester to Students in Bahamas Displaced by Hurricane
headline.print_headline: Free Semester For Storm-Hit To Be Offered By University

articles.snippet: Most residents in eastern North Carolina, where people rattle off the names of storms like old enemies, were spared the worst from Dorian. But they haven’t all recovered from last year’s flooding.
articles.lead_paragraph: BURGAW, N.C. — Every other house along the dirt road hugging a stretch of Burgaw Creek sat empty — sold off or abandoned after years of hurricanes and worsening floods. Then there was Elizabeth Rivenbark’s place.
articles.abstract: Most residents in eastern North Carolina, where people rattle off the names of storms like old enemies, were spared the worst from Dorian. But they haven’t all recovered from last year’s flooding.

headline.main: They Survived Dorian but Wonder How Many More Hurricanes They Can Withstand
headline.print_headline: Relief After Winds Subside, but ‘Every Year It’s Worse and Worse’

byline.original: By Jack Healy and Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs

articles.snippet: The blow to the Outer Banks, a 120-mile strand of narrow barrier islands off North Carolina that is a magnet for hurricanes, was a reminder of the menacing power the storm retained.
articles.lead_paragraph: NAGS HEAD, N.C. — Hurricane Dorian finally made landfall in the United States on Friday morning on North Carolina’s Outer Banks, where it knocked out power, flooded homes and businesses, and temporarily trapped residents of remote Ocracoke Island, where floodwaters reached up to seven feet.
articles.abstract: The blow to the Outer Banks, a 120-mile strand of narrow barrier islands off North Carolina that is a magnet for hurricanes, was a reminder of the menacing power the storm retained.

headline.main: ‘I’ll Just Have to Restart Everything’: Ocracoke Island Is Hit Hard by Dorian
headline.print_headline: Still-Powerful Storm Batters the Outer Banks, Then Churns Back Out to Sea

byline.original: By Campbell Robertson, Richard Fausset and Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs

articles.snippet: The small community of Treasure Cay, left without power, water or communication, is wrestling with the vast destruction wrought by the hurricane.
articles.lead_paragraph: TREASURE CAY, Bahamas — Since Hurricane Dorian plowed through Stafford Symonette’s house, and with it much of his community of Treasure Cay, he has stopped by from time to time to visit the ruins of his home.
articles.abstract: The small community of Treasure Cay, left without power, water or communication, is wrestling with the vast destruction wrought by the hurricane.

headline.main: How One Bahamian Town, Nearly Destroyed, Is Coping After Dorian
headline.print_headline: Amid Debris in the Bahamas, ‘This Was a Restaurant Here’

articles.snippet: Homeowners shouldn’t expect the process to be easy. Insurers, one consumer advocate said, are increasingly shifting more risk to customers.
articles.lead_paragraph: As Hurricane Dorian churned north this week, residents along the Atlantic coast were preparing to assess the possible damage to their homes, and to determine what their insurance policies will cover.

articles.snippet: The tiny island nation, with just 0.1 percent of the United States population, has been overwhelmed by the catastrophic storm. Its residents are losing patience with their government’s response.
articles.lead_paragraph: MARSH HARBOUR, the Bahamas — In the hours and days after Hurricane Dorian tore through the Bahamas’ Abaco Islands, the first government rescuers many residents saw were American. Coast Guard helicopters cut through the sky to evacuate the sick and wounded.
articles.abstract: The tiny island nation, with just 0.1 percent of the United States population, has been overwhelmed by the catastrophic storm. Its residents are losing patience with their government’s response.

headline.main: In Bahamas, Battered Residents Ask: Where Is Our Government?
headline.print_headline: Desperate Bahamians Ask: ‘Where Are Our First Responders?’

byline.original: By Kirk Semple, Frances Robles, Rachel Knowles and Elisabeth Malkin

articles.snippet: The Category 1 storm made landfall on the Outer Banks, where some people climbed into the attics of their homes to avoid surging floodwaters.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hurricane Dorian, the storm that devastated the Bahamas and put much of the southeastern United States on edge, battered the coast of North Carolina with heavy rain, wind and flooding on Friday, after making landfall on the Outer Banks.
articles.abstract: The Category 1 storm made landfall on the Outer Banks, where some people climbed into the attics of their homes to avoid surging floodwaters.

articles.snippet: New data shows some of the major challenges facing United States disaster policy, even as climate change increases those risks.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Most of the homes threatened by Hurricane Dorian do not have flood insurance, which means the damage from the storm may be long-lasting.
articles.abstract: New data shows some of the major challenges facing United States disaster policy, even as climate change increases those risks.

headline.main: Almost 2 Million Homes Are at Risk From Dorian. Most Lack Flood Insurance.

articles.snippet: The rush to fill flights and ferries has raised questions about what immigration rules apply for Bahamians seeking refuge.
articles.lead_paragraph: NASSAU, the Bahamas — Destitute survivors of Hurricane Dorian who lost much of what they had to the powerful storm packed a government office in the Bahamas on Monday, desperate for a document that could be their ticket off the overwhelmed islands: a clean criminal record.
articles.abstract: The rush to fill flights and ferries has raised questions about what immigration rules apply for Bahamians seeking refuge.

headline.main: Bahamas Hurricane Survivors, Desperate for Respite, Seek Passage to U.S.

byline.original: By Rachel Knowles, Frances Robles, Caitlin Dickerson and Patricia Mazzei

articles.snippet: Wilbur L. Ross Jr. made the threat after the agency’s Alabama office contradicted the president’s claim that Hurricane Dorian might hit the state.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Secretary of Commerce threatened to fire top employees at the federal scientific agency responsible for weather forecasts last Friday after the agency’s Birmingham office contradicted President Trump’s claim that Hurricane Dorian might hit Alabama, according to three people familiar with the discussion.
articles.abstract: Wilbur L. Ross Jr. made the threat after the agency’s Alabama office contradicted the president’s claim that Hurricane Dorian might hit the state.

headline.main: Commerce Chief Threatened Firings at NOAA After Trump’s Dorian Tweets, Sources Say
headline.print_headline: U.S. Secretary Said to Coerce NOAA Leaders

byline.original: By Peter Baker, Christopher Flavelle and Lisa Friedman

articles.snippet: The  House Science Committee opened an inquiry into a report that the commerce secretary threatened firings at the agency after some forecasters contradicted President Trump.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A congressional committee opened an inquiry on Wednesday into a report that the secretary of commerce, Wilbur L. Ross Jr., coerced the head of a federal science agency into supporting President Trump’s erroneous statements about Hurricane Dorian.
articles.abstract: The  House Science Committee opened an inquiry into a report that the commerce secretary threatened firings at the agency after some forecasters contradicted President Trump.

headline.main: House Panel to Investigate Report That Cabinet Official Coerced NOAA Chief

byline.original: By Christopher Flavelle and Lisa Friedman

articles.snippet: Equinor, the Norwegian company that owns terminals damaged in the storm, said it was investigating whether they were the source.
articles.lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Oil is contaminating a section of coastline in the Bahamas, leaving blackened slicks along the coast and in the water days after a Norwegian company reported that Hurricane Dorian had blown the tops off oil storage tanks.
articles.abstract: Equinor, the Norwegian company that owns terminals damaged in the storm, said it was investigating whether they were the source.

headline.main: Oil Befouls Bahamas Coastline After Hurricane Dorian

articles.snippet: The remarks by Neil Jacobs, head of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, were the first since a report that a cabinet secretary had tried to coerce agency leaders.
articles.lead_paragraph: HUNTSVILLE, Ala. — Neil Jacobs, head of the federal scientific agency threatened with firings after one of its offices contradicted President Trump on Hurricane Dorian, defended the administration Tuesday even as he issued a carefully worded defense of agency scientists.
articles.abstract: The remarks by Neil Jacobs, head of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, were the first since a report that a cabinet secretary had tried to coerce agency leaders.

headline.main: NOAA Chief, Defending Trump on Dorian, Also Tries to Buoy Scientists

articles.snippet: After the Category 5 hurricane, companies that often have a difficult relationship with the Bahamas have stepped in to help with relief. But is it enough to repair their image?
articles.lead_paragraph: At 76, disabled, with half the roof of her Grand Bahama home blown off and facing the prospect of months without electricity, Myrtle Cartwright decided she had to leave.
articles.abstract: After the Category 5 hurricane, companies that often have a difficult relationship with the Bahamas have stepped in to help with relief. But is it enough to repair their image?

articles.lead_paragraph: NASSAU, Bahamas — About 2,500 people have been reported missing in the Bahamas in the wake of Hurricane Dorian, but the names have yet to be checked against those who evacuated or sought shelter, the government said Wednesday.

articles.snippet: The controversy has dragged one of the country's preeminent research agencies, famous for being anonymous, into the spotlight it long avoided.
articles.lead_paragraph: SILVER SPRING, Md. — On Friday morning in the suburbs of Washington, D.C., government scientists in khakis and sensible shoes bustled to work — beneath a towering bronze sculpture of a hand releasing seabirds — heading for a  small scientific agency caught up in a political mess triggered by President Trump’s tweet about Hurricane Dorian.
articles.abstract: The controversy has dragged one of the country's preeminent research agencies, famous for being anonymous, into the spotlight it long avoided.

headline.main: Trump’s Dorian Tweet Whips Up a Fight Over a Science Powerhouse
headline.print_headline: Trump’s Hurricane Tweet Pushes NOAA Into the Political Arena

articles.snippet: A weather system could bring up to six inches of rain and prompt flooding in an area already battered by Hurricane Dorian.
articles.lead_paragraph: NASSAU, Bahamas — A potential tropical storm is brewing in the Atlantic and by late Friday could threaten areas of the Bahamas recently devastated by Hurricane Dorian, forecasters warned.
articles.abstract: A weather system could bring up to six inches of rain and prompt flooding in an area already battered by Hurricane Dorian.

headline.main: New Potential Tropical Storm Threatens Bahamas

articles.snippet: More than 2,000 people evacuated to Nassau from ravaged islands, almost all Haitian, are in shelters with nowhere to go. ‘Some dogs are living better.’

articles.abstract: More than 2,000 people evacuated to Nassau from ravaged islands, almost all Haitian, are in shelters with nowhere to go. ‘Some dogs are living better.’

byline.original: By Frances Robles and Rachel Knowles

articles.snippet: A new report puts 2019 on pace to be one of the most disastrous years in almost two decades even before the effects of Hurricane Dorian on the Bahamas are tallied. But there was also good news.
articles.lead_paragraph: Extreme weather events displaced a record seven million people from their homes during the first six months of this year, a figure that put 2019 on pace to be one of the most disastrous years in almost two decades even before Hurricane Dorian battered the Bahamas.
articles.abstract: A new report puts 2019 on pace to be one of the most disastrous years in almost two decades even before the effects of Hurricane Dorian on the Bahamas are tallied. But there was also good news.

headline.main: Extreme Weather Displaced a Record 7 Million in First Half of 2019
headline.print_headline: 7 Million Fled Disasters Tied To Weather In 6 Months

articles.snippet: The Bahamas had been bracing for a possible direct hit, but heavy rain appeared to be the worst of a new storm’s impact.
articles.lead_paragraph: NASSAU, the Bahamas — The Bahamas breathed a sigh of relief as a new storm changed course on Saturday and skirted the islands that were devastated by Hurricane Dorian less than two weeks ago.
articles.abstract: The Bahamas had been bracing for a possible direct hit, but heavy rain appeared to be the worst of a new storm’s impact.

headline.main: Bahamas Is Spared as Tropical Storm Humberto Moves Away
headline.print_headline: Pummeled Islands in Bahamas Escape a 2nd Blow

byline.original: By Rachel Knowles and Kirk Semple

articles.snippet: Tornadoes are the most challenging tempests that the National Weather Service workers in Alabama typically handle. But all that changed with a faulty Hurricane Dorian tweet by the president.
articles.lead_paragraph: CALERA, Ala. — It had been a sleepy Sunday morning in the National Weather Service’s office outside of Birmingham. The hot temperatures in the forecast were not out of the ordinary for the waning days of summer. There was a faraway tropical storm that the office was keeping an eye on — one with the name of Dorian —  but with each passing day, it seemed more likely to veer in a different direction.
articles.abstract: Tornadoes are the most challenging tempests that the National Weather Service workers in Alabama typically handle. But all that changed with a faulty Hurricane Dorian tweet by the president.

headline.main: All Was Quiet at the Birmingham Weather Office. Until a Trump Forecast Brought a Storm.
headline.print_headline: Sleepy Morning at a Weather Hub, Then a Trumpian Tempest

byline.original: By Steve Eder and Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs

articles.snippet: The 700-island nation is in mourning after the devastation of Hurricane Dorian. But with the country dependent upon tourism, travel officials say that many hotels and resorts are open and eager for visitors.
articles.lead_paragraph: The first sign that something is amiss at the Atlantis resort on Paradise Island comes before even stepping inside: The Bahamian flag perched on the roof is flying at half-staff.
articles.abstract: The 700-island nation is in mourning after the devastation of Hurricane Dorian. But with the country dependent upon tourism, travel officials say that many hotels and resorts are open and eager for visitors.

headline.main: The Bahamas’ Big Need Is Tourists, It Says
headline.print_headline: Want to Help the Bahamas? Vacation There

articles.snippet: When the time comes to assess the environmental damage from Hurricane Dorian, one species may be extinct, but it's not Dorian's fault
articles.lead_paragraph: In a catastrophic hurricane like Dorian, the loss of lives and homes can be overwhelming. But even in the midst of devastating sadness and disbelief, a far less urgent but perennial question can tug at the back of the mind. What is the impact of these storms on wild creatures, like birds?
articles.abstract: When the time comes to assess the environmental damage from Hurricane Dorian, one species may be extinct, but it's not Dorian's fault

headline.main: Hurricanes May Kill Some Birds, but Humans Are the Real Threat
headline.print_headline: Birds’ Top Danger? Humans

articles.snippet: The storm is expected to weaken over the next few days.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hurricane Jerry strengthened to a Category 2 storm on Friday with maximum sustained winds of 100 miles per hour. It was one of several storms churning at the midpoint of the Atlantic hurricane season, as Texas reels from the effects of the former Tropical Storm Imelda, which made landfall this week, and the Bahamas digs out from the devastation of Hurricane Dorian this month.
articles.abstract: The storm is expected to weaken over the next few days.

headline.main: Hurricane Jerry Strengthens to a Category 2 in the Atlantic

byline.original: By Aimee Ortiz and Derrick Bryson Taylor

articles.snippet: Forecasters said the storm may circle back over its own track and head west toward the Bahamas, which were devastated by Hurricane Dorian.
articles.lead_paragraph: Tropical Storm Karen, which was headed north into open water on Wednesday, is expected to perform a loop-de-loop, cross back over its own track and swing west toward the Bahamas and Florida.
articles.abstract: Forecasters said the storm may circle back over its own track and head west toward the Bahamas, which were devastated by Hurricane Dorian.

headline.main: Tropical Storm Karen Could Loop Toward the Bahamas and Florida
headline.print_headline: Storm Chugs Out to Sea, but Might Be Turning Around

articles.snippet: The government of the Bahamas has prohibited rebuilding in the Haitian shantytowns destroyed by the Category 5 storm in early September.
articles.lead_paragraph: The government of the Bahamas has prohibited rebuilding in the Haitian shantytowns destroyed by the Category 5 storm in early September.
articles.abstract: The government of the Bahamas has prohibited rebuilding in the Haitian shantytowns destroyed by the Category 5 storm in early September.

headline.main: They Survived Hurricane Dorian. Their Community Will Not.

byline.original: By K.K. Rebecca Lai, Derek Watkins, Niko Koppel and Anjali Singhvi

articles.snippet: Dorian devastated this place, but hope keeps washing ashore.
articles.lead_paragraph: OCRACOKE, N.C. — I write this from a barrier island 26 miles off the mainland coast, accessible only by boat or plane. It has been about three weeks since Hurricane Dorian blew through, tore up and submerged the place that my 1,000 or so neighbors and I call home. While it might seem from a distance that the storm has passed, we are all as shellshocked as we were on Day 1.
articles.abstract: Dorian devastated this place, but hope keeps washing ashore.

headline.main: Message From a Proud Island: ‘We Need Your Help’
headline.print_headline: From a Proud Island: ‘We Need Your Help’

articles.snippet: Knowing the answer might force us toward a real solution.
articles.lead_paragraph: If the summer heat, followed by Hurricane Dorian, hasn’t convinced you that climate change is real, probably nothing will. Those of us convinced will want to mitigate it if we can. Doing that requires understanding the different kinds of problems climate change presents. They are economic, political and philosophical. The three kinds of problems are inextricably intertwined. That’s one lesson taught by the relatively new discipline of politics, philosophy and economics (PPE).
articles.abstract: Knowing the answer might force us toward a real solution.

headline.main: What Kind of Problem Is Climate Change?

articles.snippet: The issue of illegal immigration from Haiti to the Bahamas has spanned decades, with Haitian nationals long stigmatized in the country.
articles.lead_paragraph: NASSAU, Bahamas — More than 100 Haitian migrants were deported on Thursday, six weeks after Hurricane Dorian leveled Abaco and Grand Bahama in the northern Bahamas with a devastating wallop that struck the Haitian community especially hard.
articles.abstract: The issue of illegal immigration from Haiti to the Bahamas has spanned decades, with Haitian nationals long stigmatized in the country.

headline.main: Haitian Migrants, Devastated by Dorian, Face Deportation From Bahamas
headline.print_headline: Bahamas Resumes Deportations of Haitian Migrants Weeks After Storm

articles.snippet: Powerful tropical storms occur all around the world, but what they’re called depends on where they form.
articles.lead_paragraph: When a tropical storm pummeled Japan on Saturday with gusts of up to 135 miles per hour, forcing millions to evacuate their homes, it was called Typhoon Hagibis. But the storm that carved a path of destruction across the Bahamas in September was Hurricane Dorian. And when the most powerful storm to hit Bangladesh in years destroyed thousands of homes in May, it was called Cyclone Fani.
articles.abstract: Powerful tropical storms occur all around the world, but what they’re called depends on where they form.

headline.main: Typhoon, Cyclone or Hurricane? Different Names for the Same Storms

byline.original: By Mariel Padilla and Jennifer Jett

articles.abstract: Scientists assembled a 1,500-year history of big storm activity by retrieving sediment from the island country’s submarine caverns.
articles.snippet: Scientists assembled a 1,500-year history of big storm activity by retrieving sediment from the island country’s submarine caverns.
articles.lead_paragraph: Katrina. Harvey. Maria. Dorian. In recent years, hurricanes have killed thousands of people and caused billions of dollars in damage. But getting a handle on how frequently these destructive storms have pummeled the planet is tough because records stretch back only about a century and a half.

headline.main: In the Blue Holes of the Bahamas, Secrets of Hurricanes Past
headline.print_headline: Sedimentary: In Blue Holes Of Bahamas, Secrets Of Hurricanes Past

articles.abstract: The cows, believed to have been carried out to sea when the storm hit North Carolina, have been spotted hanging out on the Outer Banks.

articles.lead_paragraph: Hurricane Dorian slammed into North Carolina as a Category 1 storm on Sept. 6, lashing the state with heavy rain, wind and flooding after it made landfall on the Outer Banks, a chain of narrow barrier islands off the main coast.

articles.abstract: Despite the damage inflicted by Hurricane Dorian, investment dollars continue to flow into the Atlantic Ocean archipelago.
articles.snippet: Despite the damage inflicted by Hurricane Dorian, investment dollars continue to flow into the Atlantic Ocean archipelago.
articles.lead_paragraph: This three-bedroom house sits on the banks of a canal in Old Fort Bay, a gated community of 250 homes on the northwest coast of New Providence, the most populous island in the Bahamas.

headline.main: House Hunting in the Bahamas: Comfort on the Waters of Nassau
headline.print_headline: A Touch of Venice in a Tropical Clime
